conclusion: Analyze the flow of liquid from points A, B, and C to determine whether each will end up in container D or E.
The image shows three input points (A, B, C) at the top where liquid will flow from, multiple colored baffles (angled rods) in the middle section, and two collection containers (D, E) at the bottom.
The liquid will follow gravity and bounce off the baffles it encounters along the way.
Starting from point A (leftmost pink marker), liquid drops straight down until it hits the red baffle.
The red baffle is angled down and to the right, so liquid will deflect rightward.
After the red baffle, it may hit the brown baffle, which is angled to direct flow left.
Following these deflections, the liquid continues down.
Based on the trajectory, the liquid from A will most likely flow into container D (red container).
Starting from point B (light blue/mint marker in middle), liquid drops straight down until it hits the green baffle.
The green baffle deflects the liquid to the right.
It may then encounter the purple baffle, which would deflect it slightly left.
Following the path downward.
Based on this trajectory, the liquid from B will most likely flow into container D (red container).
Starting from point C (rightmost green marker), liquid drops straight down until it hits either the purple baffle or possibly the orange baffle.
If it hits the purple baffle, it will be deflected left.
Following this path downward.
Based on this trajectory, the liquid from C will most likely flow into container E (green container).
Liquid from point A will flow into container D.
Liquid from point B will flow into container D.
Liquid from point C will flow into container E.
